description: Clipping of hockamore, from the name of the German town of Hochheim am Main.

entries.meaning: A Rhenish wine, of a light yellow color, either sparkling or still, from the Hochheim region; often applied to all Rhenish wines.

description: From Middle English hough, hoche, hokke, from Old English hōh, from Proto-Germanic *hanhaz (compare West Frisian hakke, Dutch hak, German Low German Hack), from Proto-Indo-European *kenk- (compare Lithuanian kìnka (“leg, thigh, knee-cap”), kenklė̃ (“knee-cap”), Sanskrit कङ्काल (kaṅkāla, “skeleton”)).

entries.meaning: The tarsal joint of a digitigrade quadruped, such as a horse, pig or dog.
Meat from that part of a food animal.

verbs.description: hock (third-person singular simple present hocks, present participle hocking, simple past and past participle hocked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disable by cutting the tendons of the hock; to hamstring; to hough.

description: From the phrase in hock, circa 1855-60, from Dutch hok (“hutch, hovel, jail, pen, doghouse”).  Compare also Middle English hukken (“to sell; peddle; sell at auction”), see huck.

entries.meaning: Pawn, obligation as collateral for a loan.
examples: He needed $750 to get his guitar out of hock at the pawnshop.
They were in hock to the bank for $35 million.

verbs.description: hock (third-person singular simple present hocks, present participle hocking, simple past and past participle hocked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To leave with a pawnbroker as security for a loan.

description: From Yiddish האַק‎ (hak), imperative singular form of האַקן‎ (hakn, “to knock”), from the idiomatic expression האַק מיר נישט קיין טשײַניק‎ (hak mir nisht keyn tshaynik, “don't knock a teakettle at me”).

verbs.description: hock (third-person singular simple present hocks, present participle hocking, simple past and past participle hocked)

entries.meaning: (US) To bother; to pester; to annoy incessantly.

description: Variant of hack; from Middle English hacken, hakken, from Old English *haccian ("to hack"; attested in tōhaccian (“to hack to pieces”)), from Proto-Germanic *hakkōną (“to chop; hoe; hew”), from Proto-Indo-European *keg-, *keng- (“to be sharp; peg; hook; handle”).

verbs.description: hock (third-person singular simple present hocks, present participle hocking, simple past and past participle hocked)

definitionGroups.group: To cough heavily, especially causing uvular frication.

entries.meaning: To cough while the vomit reflex is triggered; to gag.
To produce mucus from coughing or clearing one's throat.
(card games) The last card turned up in the game of faro.
